articles.headline: Office Mandates. Pickleball. Beer. What Will Make Hybrid Work Stick?
articles.snippet: Hybrid work has been choose-your-own-adventure, but now C.E.O.s are making their choices more permanent.
articles.abstract: Hybrid work has been choose-your-own-adventure, but now C.E.O.s are making their choices more permanent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The freight elevator doors opened onto 50,000 square feet of office real estate. Right now, it is empty, but Seth Besmertnik, chief executive of the software company Conductor, gestured at the beams and concrete floor with pride. He has plans for his company’s new office — conference rooms, a pickleball court and, of course, all of his 200 employees in the New York City area.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg and Hilary Swift

articles.headline: Ron DeSantis Usually Avoids the Press. For Murdoch, He’ll Make an Exception.
articles.snippet: The Florida governor granted a rare interview to The Times of London, one of several Murdoch media properties he’s spoken with as he prepares a possible presidential bid.
articles.abstract: The Florida governor granted a rare interview to The Times of London, one of several Murdoch media properties he’s spoken with as he prepares a possible presidential bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, a sulfurous critic of the news media, has all but shunned one-on-one interviews with mainstream political reporters, speaking almost exclusively in recent months with friendly conservative pundits.

articles.headline: Alex Murdaugh Convicted of Murdering Wife and Son
articles.snippet: The verdict came less than three hours after jurors began deliberating. It followed a six-week trial that served as a reckoning for Mr. Murdaugh, a lawyer whose life unraveled in recent years.
articles.abstract: The verdict came less than three hours after jurors began deliberating. It followed a six-week trial that served as a reckoning for Mr. Murdaugh, a lawyer whose life unraveled in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALTERBORO, S.C. — Alex Murdaugh, the fourth-generation lawyer whose family long exerted influence in small-town courtrooms across parts of South Carolina, was convicted on Thursday of murdering his wife and son, sealing the dramatic downfall of a man who had substantial wealth and powerful connections but who lived a secret life in which he stole millions of dollars from clients and colleagues and lied to many of those closest to him.

articles.headline: In First Wartime Meeting, Blinken Confronts His Russian Counterpart
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he told Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, that Moscow must end its war against Ukraine and return to a nuclear arms control treaty.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he told Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, that Moscow must end its war against Ukraine and return to a nuclear arms control treaty.
articles.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and his Russian counterpart on Thursday held the first private, face-to-face exchange between a U.S. cabinet member and a top Kremlin official since the invasion, and Mr. Blinken said he used the encounter to demand that Russia end its war on Ukraine.

articles.headline: As A.I. Booms, Lawmakers Struggle to Understand the Technology
articles.snippet: Tech innovations are again racing ahead of Washington’s ability to regulate them, lawmakers and A.I. experts said.
articles.abstract: Tech innovations are again racing ahead of Washington’s ability to regulate them, lawmakers and A.I. experts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, two members of Congress have sounded the alarm over the dangers of artificial intelligence.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: They Sneaked Into a Derelict Arms Plant: Instagrammers or Spies?
articles.snippet: Three people, including two Russians, arrested on charges of entering an abandoned rifle factory have puzzled Albanian authorities at a time when suspicions about Moscow have been mounting.
articles.abstract: Three people, including two Russians, arrested on charges of entering an abandoned rifle factory have puzzled Albanian authorities at a time when suspicions about Moscow have been mounting.
articles.lead_paragraph: The three espionage suspects — two Russians and one Ukrainian — were hardly discreet.

articles.headline: Condemning Murdaugh’s ‘Lies,’ Judge Sentences Him to Life in Prison
articles.snippet: The sentence was the maximum that the judge could hand down for the murders of Alex Murdaugh’s wife and son, given that prosecutors had not sought the death penalty.
articles.abstract: The sentence was the maximum that the judge could hand down for the murders of Alex Murdaugh’s wife and son, given that prosecutors had not sought the death penalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALTERBORO, S.C. — A judge sentenced Alex Murdaugh to life in prison on Friday for the murders of his wife and son, condemning the once-wealthy and influential Southern lawyer to spend the remainder of his life behind bars, a powerful rebuke from the rural South Carolina legal system that his family dominated for more than a century.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Jacey Fortin

articles.headline: Alabama Mining Strike Ends Without a Deal After Nearly 2 Years
articles.snippet: The strike at the Warrior Met Coal mine was one of the longest in U.S. history, but the price of coal soared during the walkout, giving the company leverage.
articles.abstract: The strike at the Warrior Met Coal mine was one of the longest in U.S. history, but the price of coal soared during the walkout, giving the company leverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of coal miners in Alabama have been told by their union that they can start returning to work before a contract deal has been reached, bringing an unceremonious end to one of the longest mining strikes in U.S. history.
